title: Uniform Sampling on a Unit Disk
text:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# 1. Sample the points
N = 10000
inv_cdf = lambda x: np.sqrt(x)
R = np.vectorize(inv_cdf)(np.random.uniform(0, 1, N))
T = np.random.uniform(0, 2*np.pi, N)
points = [(r * np.cos(t), r * np.sin(t)) for r, t in zip(R, T)]

# 2. Make a scatter plot
x, y = zip(*points)
plt.scatter(x, y, s=1)
plt.xticks([])
plt.yticks([])
ax = plt.gca()
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.spines['top'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['right'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['bottom'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['left'].set_visible(False)
plt.show()

title: How to Break Nested For Loop
text: Using a few examples, we demonstrate how to conditionally break out of nested for loop using for-else clause.

title: How to Break Nested For Loop
How to Break Nested For Loop
text:
2 Double Nested for Loop
Here, the program halts right after (i,j) reaches (2,1), which is what we want.

for i in range(4): # Layer 1
    print(f"Layer 1 for i = {i}: start")
    for j in range(3): # Layer 2
        print(f"  {i} {j}")
        if (i, j) == (2, 1):
            break
    else: # reached <=> for loop layer 2 was broken
        print(f"  Layer 2 for i = {i}: finished")
        continue # continuing for the enclosing for loop (layer 1), thus ignoring the "break"
    break # reached <=> continue was not called <=> for loop layer 2 was broken

Layer 1 for i = 0: start
  0 0
  0 1
  0 2
  Layer 2 for i = 0: finished
Layer 1 for i = 1: start
  1 0
  1 1
  1 2
  Layer 2 for i = 1: finished
Layer 1 for i = 2: start
  2 0
  2 1


Here, no continue in the else part. Thus, the program breaks unconditionally after finishing its job in the i==0 round.

for i in range(4):
    print(f"Layer 1 for i = {i}: start")
    for j in range(3):
        print(f"  {i} {j}")
        if (i, j) == (2, 1):
            break
    else: # reached <=> the for loop layer 2 was broken
        print(f"  Layer 2 for i = {i}: completed")
    break # always reached at i = 0

Layer 1 for i = 0: start
  0 0
  0 1
  0 2
  Layer 2 for i = 0: completed

title: How to Break Nested For Loop
text:
3 Triple Nested for Loop
OK, we’ve learnt enough. Now, let’s test it on a triple nested for loop!

for i in range(3):
    for j in range(4):
        for k in range(2):
            print(i, j, k)
            if (i,j,k) == (1,2,0):
                break
        else:
            continue
        break
    else:
        continue
    break

title: Inverse Sampling Transform
text: Throughout this article, we use the following notations:

title: Inverse Sampling Transform
text:
1 Background

Proposition 1 For any random variable X, we have 
    X = F_X^{-1}(U).



Proof. For any x, we have 
    P(X \le x) = F_X(x) = P(U \le F_X(x)) = P(F_X^{-1}(U) \le x).
 Thus X = F_X^{-1}(U).

title: Inverse Sampling Transform
section: 2 Application: Uniform Sampling on a Disk
text:
2 Application: Uniform Sampling on a Disk
Now, we want to perform uniform sampling on the unit disk. We use polar coordinates; more specifically, we take r\cos(\theta), r\sin(\theta), where

r \in [0,1] such that P(r) \propto r (\Rightarrow P(r) = 2r)
\theta \sim U(0,2\pi)

The key lies in 1., that is, how to sample r such that P(r) = 2r. Let X be the random variable such that P(X = r) = 2r. Then, F_X(x) = \int_0^x 2r\,dr = x^2, and thus F_X^{-1}(y) = \sqrt{y}.

2.1 Code
With above in mind, we sample 10000 points on the unit disk, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# 1. Sample the points
N = 10000
inv_cdf = lambda x: np.sqrt(x)
R = np.vectorize(inv_cdf)(np.random.uniform(0, 1, N))
T = np.random.uniform(0, 2*np.pi, N)
points = [(r * np.cos(t), r * np.sin(t)) for r, t in zip(R, T)]

# 2. Make a scatter plot
x, y = zip(*points)
plt.scatter(x, y, s=1)
plt.xticks([])
plt.yticks([])
ax = plt.gca()
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.spines['top'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['right'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['bottom'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['left'].set_visible(False)
plt.show()





Figure 1: Sampling 10000 points uniformly on the unit disk.
